noun.description: Failure to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or appear in a court of law.
examples: it will have to restructure its debts to avoid default
the deteriorating economy pushed defaults to almost $20 billion

noun.description: A preselected option adopted by a computer program or other mechanism when no alternative is specified by the user or programmer.

verb.description: Fail to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or to appear in a court of law.
examples: some had defaulted on student loans

verb.description: (of a computer program or other mechanism) revert automatically to (a preselected option)
examples: when you start a fresh letter the system will default to its own style

phrases: they won the last election by default
The opposite, by default, must then be the definition of an anti-politician.
Efforts to support an uprising around a weak opposition fail and strengthen him by default.
Perhaps they will be re-elected in the next elections by default, with no-one having voted!
The movement was partially empowered by default of serious opposition.
origin: Middle English: from Old French defaut, from defaillir to fail, based on Latin fallere disappoint, deceive.
